Consider an algebra ⟨R; +, −, 0, ⋅, 1⟩ such that: i) ⟨R; +, −, 0⟩ is a group. ii) ⟨R; ⋅, 1⟩ is a monoid. iii) a(b + c) = ab + ac and (b + c)a = ba + ca for all a, b, c, ∈ R. Prove that such an algebra satisfies Definition 5.18 in the lecture notes. Each step should consist of one or more applications of the given axioms, and the axioms used should be made explicit. Hint: consider (1 + 1)(a + b). Proof: Let's consider the case (1 + 1)(a + b). We have proven that the operation + on the algebra ⟨R; +, −, 0, ⋅, 1⟩ is commutative. The algebra is thus proven to be a ring. Definition 5.18. A ring ⟨R; +, −, 0, ⋅, 1⟩ is an algebra for which (i) ⟨R; +, −, 0⟩ is a (commutative) group (ii) ⟨R; ⋅, 1⟩ is a monoid. (iii) a(b + c) = (ab) + (ac) and (b + c)a = (ba) + (ca) for all a, b, c ∈ R (left and right distributive laws). A ring is called commutative if multiplication is commutative (ab = ba) Lemma 5.17.
